messageBody:
Hallo Steve and folks...

> If people spell as they speak and they use a
> regional dialect, their
> transcriptions are not going to match those with
> other accents.

True: and that, (for me), is part of the attraction
of learning a phonetic script.

> One almost needs a pronunciation dictionary for
> every major dialect
> of English. www.fonetik.com has started moving in
> this direction.

And then of course, you need to _keep_ moving, because
accent change is a much more fluid process than
spelling change. A Birmingham or a Dublin accent is
quite different from a their equivalents 50 years ago.
I guess the change is going to be slower for MAJOR
dialects, but it's bound to happen.

>A standardized phonemic
> system would also
> standardize pronunciation or at least require that
> some words be
> repronounced in order to be spelled correctly.

So the mental acrobatics required for reading from a
standardised phonemic system can be the same as those
required to read from a non-standardised phonemic
system i.e. "phonetically that word says X, whereas I
would pronounce it Y, but I recognise it as meaning Z
anyway."

With all that in mind, is a BIG widely used spelling
reform system any use to anyone? is it worth
campaigning for? what's wrong with just using as a
personal note taking system or as a kind of 'light'
phonetic transcription system?

just asking - regards,
Michael
